nightingale20201 morning all
BE11:09am

DBRS considers that diverging views on Brexit among citizens in the UK could inadvertently lead to the breakup of the Union. DBRS reviews the implications of no-deal scenarios and their potential impact on the unity of the United Kingdom. At one extreme is a “severe” hard Brexit whereby the UK crashes out of the EU permanently with no airbags or restraints on its impact. DBRS concludes that such a Brexit could quickly change the support for Scottish independence and even over time the support for the unication of Ireland, increasing the breakup risk of the UK. These considerations are exacerbated by a weakening economic environment that intensies divisions within the UK.

IMP.GLD Someone was paid for that analysis?
BE11:10am

http://www.dbrs.com if you want to read the full thing.

Grouchmonkey Morning
wayneJ Surely the portrait of the day ought to be our dear Leader of the House - JRM?
11:10 am
BE11:11am

Or for something a bit more nuanced, here's Kallum Pickering at Berenberg.

BE11:11am

No hiding from markets: Since the UK’s European Union Referendum Bill was unveiled in the queen’s speech in May 2015, sterling has fallen by c26% against the euro and c29% against the dollar. By comparison, trade-weighted sterling dropped by c27% peak-to-trough during the financial crisis of 2007-09.

BE11:11am

The economics of a hard Brexit: In the short run, severe border disruption, a major drop in confidence from high uncertainty, and a rise in inflation due to a weaker sterling could tip the UK into recession. In the long run, switching to bare-bones WTO trade rules for UK-EU trade could depress UK potential growth from c2.1% – inside the EU – to as low as c1.5%. Reduced inflows of migrants to the UK would weaken employment gains. Lower growth in trade and investment between the UK and the EU could reduce long-run productivity growth.

wayneJ Various photoshopped versions of JRM floating around but there is one missing - someone needs to redress him as the Emperor Nero.....
11:11 am
BE11:11am

How much hard-Brexit risk is priced into the pound? In our view, fair value for sterling versus the euro in an orderly Brexit is 1.20. In the event of a hard Brexit, sterling could fall to parity against the euro in the short run. Many factors determine exchange rates. Based on the current sterling-euro rate of c1.10, we calculate that the market sees a roughly 50% probability of a hard Brexit. We put the risk of a hard Brexit at 40%. Recent developments and the outlook for UK politics tilt the risk to our call to the upside.

BE11:12am

Record low gilt yields: The US-China trade war and the resulting global industrial recession have hit the UK hard. This adds to the Brexit risks. 10-year gilt yields hit a record low of 0.34% in intraday trading yesterday, down from a recent peak of 1.7% in May 2018. The fall reflects the weaker growth outlook and a market bet that the BoE would ease policy in response to a hard Brexit. We share this view. In case of a hard Brexit, we would expect the BoE to cut rates – by up to 50bp – and buy more government and corporate bonds via its quantitative easing programme.

LJ1 Morning!
BE11:12am

Consequences of the weaker sterling: On its own, the latest drop in the pound may add a few tenths of a percent to the headline inflation rate in the near term. This direct impact will be modest unless sterling drops much further. The bigger impact could be on inflation expectations, which have risen materially since the Brexit vote. After Boris Johnson became prime minister on 24 June, the UK’s five-year breakeven rate increased by c10bp to c3.3% – well above the BoE’s 2% inflation target. By comparison, the US five-year breakeven is currently c1.3%, down from c1.6% since 24 June. The lesson from Brexit so far is clear – bad economic policies cause inflation.

wayneJ Low or negative growth plus inflation = 1970s style stagflation?

Which is on this: https://www.channe...tion-bill-11871754

BE11:19am

Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam will officially withdraw the proposed extradition Bill later on Wednesday, meeting one of the protesters' key demands, local media reported citing anonymous sources.

The withdrawal of the Bill, which would have allowed Hong Kong citizens to be sent to mainland China to face trial, is one of the main demands of protesters who have plunged the city into its deepest crisis in decades.

VV75 I thought they were quite decent, considering how the other retailers are doing
11:20 am
BE11:20am

So ....... assuming it happens it's a symbolic gesture.

wayneJ (Sorry a quick aside; So Nick Soames - grandson of Churchil and Richard Benyon - great-great grandson of Lord Salisbury (PM about 100+ years ago) -- both banished on one night ---- descendants of two PMs thrown out of Tory party on one day must be a record?)
BE11:21am

And assumptions that it'll quell the protests seem optimistic, a point made this morning by Roubini / Continuum.

BE11:22am

The expected announcement from Lam is not going to have a significant material impact. Lam had already said on July 10 that the bill is “dead”. We interpreted the comments then as Hong Kong will not move the extradition bill forward further. Still, the withdrawal of the bill signals a concession from the China and Hong Kong governments. It gives an olive branch into reconciliation following 14 weeks of unrest in Hong Kong. China celebrates its 70th National Day on October 1, amid ongoing U.S./China trade tensions. A calmer Hong Kong may allow China to focus on other pressing issues.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

This also comes after several consultation sessions with senior city leaders and pro-establishment politicians. Hong Kong markets have taken the move positively. The HKD has strengthened by around 0.05% (a huge move given the HKD peg to the USD) following the news. Hong Kong stock markets have risen by more than 2% for the day. We remain unclear regarding whether the move will calm the unrests down. There are still other demands – such as an independent inquiry, amnesty and reforms. Hence, it may well be that the unrest continue, lobbying on the other demands. Should the domestic unrest continue, it is likely to weaken retail sales, investments and tourism further.
We have a generally bearish view on the Hong Kong economy, expecting GDP growth at only 1% in 2019. The economy has been dragged down by the domestic unrest, along with external factors like the U.S/China and Japan/South Korea trade wars.

hagilon hi to all
11:26 am
BE11:26am

Dunelm issued an FY Q4 trading statement in early July (just after the end of its financial year) in which it not only announced its sales figures for FY 2018/19, but guided that its profits for the year were likely to be around £126m. The actual outcome announced today (£125.9m) is unlikely to come as much of a surprise to anyone, therefore.

wayneJ @Soundbuy - Oh. Our local one has gone from ghost ship to a thriving bargain outlet with a carpark that is busy and at times most of the tills having to be manned.
BE11:26am

Although only 'in line', this is nevertheless a very good set of results, with underlying pre-tax profits up 23%. - The company has announced a special dividend of 32p per share this morning (alongside the regular final dividend of 20.5p per share).

BE11:27am

The Q4 trading statement made clear that year-end net debt was likely to be below the bottom end of the company's target leverage range [0.25-0.75x trailing 12-month EBITDA], so it was widely expected that the company would announce a cash return today.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

There is only a short comment in the statement on current trading ("recent trading has continued to be strong… however we remain cautious about the full year outlook"). As we outlined in a report a couple of months ago (see here), we believe LfLs (which averaged 10.7% in FY 2018/19) are likely to return to normal levels by the end of the calendar year [something that we believe will result in a significant de-rating of the shares].- We have yet to speak to the company this morning. However, we see little in this statement to suggest that underlying consensus forecasts will move much today According to Bloomberg, consensus is currently expecting Dunelm to report pre-tax profits of £133m in FY 2019/20 (giving EPS of 51.9p).- Based on existing consensus forecasts and last night's closing price, Dunelm is trading on 16.4x calendar 2020 earnings, 10.5x EBITDA with a 3.4% dividend yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 12.6x, 8.0x and 3.5%, respectively[though the company has provided new guidance today that IFRS 16 will likely reduce pre-tax profits by around £3m the coming year].

BE11:28am

17.5x calendar 2020 and management's talking about challenging trading, political uncertainty and strong comps.

Soundbuy We now have a Range in its place..........zzzzzzz
marktime I wonder if Barratt are cutting corners to boost margins in a market with falling price outlook
Markkus Dunelm - there's always an "informational" video telling you loudly about a frying pan that will change your life.
BE11:29am

I mean, if you see the guidance as suggesting we're near peak trading now, the derating makes a lot of sense.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

RBC:

BE11:30am

Dunelm has made an effort to refocus its offer on the core, resulting in a consistent core performance over the past year following the Worldstores
acquisition. Despite this, we still have reservations regarding Dunelm’s medium-term sales target of £2bn and think it will be challenging to achieve
this without sacrificing margin. Dunelm currently trades at c.17x FY20 P/E, near the top of its historic range of 12-20x.
We would prefer to buy B&M which was hit yesterday on concerns about a reduction in UK sales densities over the past 5-6 years, however we
believe sales densities have remained stable, excluding lower rent garden sales and space. This has allowed B&M to maintain a healthy EBITDA
margin of over 10%.

Shinshin Can't quite call it. If no deal = downturn, does that mean housing market transaction vols down = more inplace refurbs = improving sales at the DIY chains ?

IP Group PLC (IPO:LSE): Last: 57.70, up 1.9 (+3.41%), High: 58.50, Low: 56.10, Volume: 415.94k
BE11:35am

marktime Sorry, Barratt have "margin initiatives" not cost cutting measures. Boost to dividend, but is this the hole Persimmon fell into
11:34 am
BE11:35am

IP Group delayed 1H results, we hope in order to reset strategy/funding for a new environment and to attract necessary new investors: we move to Hold after a 55% 12m price fall in anticipation of a route forward. Dwindling NAV & net cash require action. Expect an update on Nanopore's listing, difficult choices between accelerating divestments of depressed listed or illiquid private co's, raising funds at a dilutive discount, cutting costs or slowing investment.

BE11:35am

65p target.

nichoman Any thoughts on spencer and Numis ? not sure there's an angle other than its cheap and at some point in future it wont be so cheap.
Patience @wayneJ - suspect fall in sterling has reduced inflow more than hostile environment. Economic migrants don't expect to be liked.
BE11:36am

Based on the 40% discount to NAV probably being sufficient pre the reboot.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

IP Group ought to be attracting interest as Great British science at a Great Big Brexit Discount, but delivering a convincing plan for returning to NAV growth and resolving funding is essential to any Buy case, without which it can be yet more friendless: discounts at peers extend to 70%.

BE11:36am

Action or Activists? Patient Capital peers Allied Minds attracted activist attention that has lead to a cost-minimising wind-up and executive clear-out. Malin has adopted a similar strategy, as had Net Scientific. IP Group is bigger, and its performance less bad (FY19E NAV of 109p is down 14% since FY15), but risks similar attention if it doesn't take matters into its own hands, we believe. 1H results on 10th September (6 weeks later than last yr) presumably allow management and board to formulate a new strategy to reflect obviously changed circumstances, sliding NAV, dwindling cash and attract a necessary new shareholder base.

BE11:37am

Course, there's the cash burn problem to fix .....

northlondon can I add to requests for coverage? Maintel and Frontier Developments please
11:38 am
BE11:38am

Cash opex of £25m pa and £121m in net cash at the end of 2018., with a closed IPO market and new equity impossible to print while shares at a deep nav discount.

BE11:38am

Hoping for the best is not a strategy, as new investors could hardly also be expected to rely on the share price doubling required to avoid NAV dilution. The options thus appear to be a combination of cost-cutting, reduced new investments, focussed/minimal support to existing holdings, and realisations where possible. None are attractive (as recent transactions like Ultrahaptics show, even better private businesses require a discount, and selling more of the listed holdings locks in depressed prices as at Circassia, Ixico, Intelligent Ultrasound) but a plan is needed.

BE11:38am

But! Nanopore!

11:39 am
BE11:39am

The sequencing unicorn. £1.5bn valuation based on the March 2018 round. That'll fix things, right?

BE11:40am

Muddling through, or pinning all of its hopes on a future Nanopore listing would seem too risky to us - and a recipe for a widening discount a la Malin (~70%, implying an IP Group price of under 40p).

Recognizing the significant share price decline, the existing discount to an NAV that we believe is largely secure (although some write-downs are always likely, and that ratio is increased if IP Group has to ration its funds), and the later-than-usual 1H results announcement (10th September vs. last year's end July) all make us begin to feel that IP group could and should be presenting a route through the cash constraints above. We move to hold, maintaining our 65p PT, with scenarios to the upside if a plausible plan is presented, or back to the downside if hope replaces planning.

nichoman anyone else caught in northern line chaos this morning ? government and tube in meltdown
BE11:41am

Reading between the lines, Jefferies seems to be suggesting a cash call to raise around £100m at a 20% discount would be sensible as part of the reboot.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

Which makes the upgrade timing pretty brave really

undefined

What's still to cover before PMQs get going? Frontier Developments, Barratt Developments .....

Kainos Group PLC (KNOS:LSE): Last: 457.00, down 38 (-7.68%), High: 506.00, Low: 449.00, Volume: 141.58k

11:48 am

Only thing I ever remember about it was that it was one of Autonomy's main reseller partners. Which .... well, I'm sure there's more to the story.

BE11:49am

BE11:50am

Due to the UK government being as per that video above.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Kainos is the leading independent player in digital transformation projects awarded under the UK's 'Digital Outcomes & Specialists' (DOS) framework and we believe the shares' recent softness has been due to investor concerns about government spending. This morning's trading statement confirms this but also highlights strong demand for enterprise services, Workday implementations & software with management expecting to meet market expectations for FY20. The comments on soft government spending tally with our proprietary data tracker which suggests a slowdown in new contract awards in the last 6 months. More than offsetting this, non-government revenues (~60% of total) should continue to grow at a

20% CAGR driven by strong demand for enterprise digital transformation work and the success of Workday. We leave FY20 estimates largely unchanged but tweak FY21&22 revenue estimates 1% to 2% lower to reflect more muted government momentum. In light of expected 10% revenue and 14% EPS FY19-22 CAGRs coupled with low single digit upside potential to consensus, the recent de-rating of the shares towards the lower end of the peer group seems overdone to us. We hence see an attractive buying opportunity for SMIDCAP investors wanting exposure to the secular growth themes of enterprise and government automation and Workday adoption.

npf1 Thx for IP Group
BE11:51am

In [earlier research] we highlighted the attractive long-term prospects of the UK's 'Digital Outcomes & Specialists' (DOS) market driven by increasing automation of government services. Kainos is the leading independent player here deriving ~40% of sales from projects for departments such as Defra, Home Office, Land Registry and others. Government data indicates spending with Kainos has remained strong so far, tracking up more than 25% yoy for 1H20 up until July. In terms of new contracts, Kainos has won ~£17m worth ytd, but the total market value of new awards so far is tracking down 31% yoy. This could be due to Brexit, implying scope for a potential year-end/post-Brexit 'flush'. However, until evidence of this emerges it is possible that we are seeing a (likely) temporary consolidation in market growth after awards more than doubled last year.

BE11:52am

That DOS apparently now means "Digital Outcomes & Specialists" makes me feel very, very old.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Anyway, govt stuff bad. Other stuff good.

BE11:53am

Kainos sees strong demand in its other growth businesses, which generate ~60% of sales and where we expect a greater than 20% CAGR going forward: 1) Digital transformation projects for enterprises helped by a push into new geographies in Europe. 2) Workday implementations and support services, which benefit from continued momentum as evidenced by last week's beat & raise' results. Kainos is the largest 'boutique' partner in Europe and management estimates that every $ spent on Workday subscriptions creates $ 1-$1.5 in implementation & support revenues. 3) Kainos' proprietary Workday testing software 'Smart' continues to win clients and is growing strongly.

BE11:53am

We nudge revenues & EPS down by 1-2% largely to reflect more muted UK government assumptions, with growth lowered from 'flat' to c. -5% in FY20&21 followed by a 5% improvement in FY22. Our new estimates imply very healthy 10% revenue and 14% EPS CAGRs for the next 3 years, which seems inconsistent with a PEG ratio of 2.0x that sits towards the lower end of listed peers. With 25% potential upside to our 620p P/E-based target (prev. 660p), we reiterate Buy.

11:53 am
undefined
BE11:54am

And so, inevitably, to DPL.

Barratt Developments PLC (BDEV:LSE): Last: 600.40, down 21.6 (-3.47%), High: 616.40, Low: 591.80, Volume: 3.02m
11:54 am
BE11:54am

Results dull and much as pre flagged.

BE11:55am

BE11:55am

Because as we know, the last thing Britain needs is for the housebuilders to build houses.

11:56 am

Barratt artificially constraining supply to support selling prices, much like a cartel operator might.

aarggh Good day to be in Macau Property. Might even be able to wind up, and get something not too far off NAV if detente lasts in HK (don't personally think it will though)
BE11:56am

Goodbody with the summary:

aarggh Anyone know why BAG is off >4% today?
BE11:57am

Barratt Developments has reported FY19 PBT of £909.8m, which is both in line with the company’s prior guidance and our forecast. Having already released most of the key financial’s in the group’s July trading update, the key takeaways for us from today’s release are: 1. Forward order book in unit terms is now +2% yoy from +12% in July with private orders -6% from -1%, affordable +7% from +17% and JV’s +13% from +60%; 2. Management notes the group is expected to deliver volume growth towards the lower end of the target range [3-5% versus Goodbody at c.-1%]; 3. Sales rates of 0.70 per site per week since the start of July are in line with the same period a year ago.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

While unsurprisingly cautious in the outlook given the political back drop,
management notes a continued focus on operational improvements and its strong financial position leaves the company well positioned to react to potential changes in the operating environment.

BE11:58am

(@aarggh: because it was up about 7% yesterday for no reason other than a positive mention in The Times.)

aarggh ah right, cheers! Missed that yesterday
BE11:59am

And Peel Hunt, which downgrades.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

There were few surprises in the final release with revenue, profits
and cash as expected, with no change to outlook, dividend return
policy or medium term strategy. While there is plenty of
uncertainty being caused by domestic politics it doesn’t seem to
have had a major impact on recent sales reservations. The shares
have had a great run in the year to date comfortably surpassing
the peers due to a better margin performance. As a result the
shares are now trading on a modest premium to the sector which
looks about right. We move our recommendation from Add to
Hold but roll our TP forward such that it rises to 650p.

Soundbuy BAG - aren't Milton dumping?
BE11:59am

And Jefferies, which doesn't.

BE12:00pm

With Barratt FY19 results largely known, we believe the focus in today's update
will be on margin potential and the cash flow generation. We would argue the
analyst meeting could still provide scope for small upgrades to forecasts from its
margin initiatives. However, balanced against lower guidance for cash flow, we
believe Barratt's share price may continue to tread water for a while given its strong
performance YTD.
FY19 results: no surprises. With PBT, net cash and dividend already reported in the
July trading update, we see little new in the FY19 numbers released this morning: PBT to £910m, net cash £766m, final ord div of 19.5p with special of 17.3p. Margin guidance remains key. Within the statement, guidance of completions growth in FY20 at lower end of 3-5% medium-term guidance was already discussed at the time of the trading update. As such, we continue to believe the main
focus will be the potential for margins. Within the statement, the group reiterates intake gross margins on land of

23% and the benefits of the new product range.

However, the analyst meeting may provide evidence of the potential benefit of its measures in place. Reporting an 18.9% EBIT margin at the time of the trading update, management highlighted the one-offs that provided benefit (legacy commercial and inventory), and consensus carries c30-50bps of margin improvement pa (ie from the 18.5% excluding one-offs to about 19-19.5%).
But guidance for FY20 cash lower. However, guidance for net cash for FY20 of £450-500m (relative to the £766m in YE19) is lower than consensus (which is flat YoY). This lower cash the group guides as driven by £80m additional cash tax (UK tax goes to current quarter rather than retrospective - so that's six quarters of cash tax in a 12-month period - relevant to all UK corporate tax payers), a reduction in land creditors (land is £3bn on balance sheet, so moving 5ppt implies £150m of cash out, and the target is to go from 31.3% to 25-30%) and a step up in land spend (£940m in FY19 moving to £1.1bn in FY20).

Soundbuy Ignore..........thought BAG was Bagir..............zzzzzzzz
marktime Do you mean Barr who make drinks the same colour on the way in as out?
Blank canvas thanks for everything today
12:01 pm
undefined
Soundbuy Aye...........cheers all
BE12:02pm

(@Marktime: you could say the same of Prieur Montrachet.)

BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR
Irish Credit Anything on Inmarsat, I work it out trading through the offer (even allowing for weakness in Sterling)
BE12:03pm

Didn't mention Frontier and there's not much to mention really .... it's a fallow year,

marktime if you are gulping it
12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

Theme Park Zoo or whatever it's called isn't out yet and Dinosaur Park Zoo is on the downslide post launch.

marktime What today does show is that markets in general are very responsive to any possibility of good news
BE12:05pm

An annualised view at this stage in Frontier's development isn't terribly useful or even interesting.

Frontier Developments PLC (FDEV:LSE): Last: 1,052, down 62 (-5.57%), High: 1,118, Low: 1,012, Volume: 80.75k
12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Have Peel Hunt anyway.

BE12:05pm

As per the trading update, FY19’s outperformance was spearheaded by Jurassic World Evolution (JWE): financials today confirmed. We make no changes to forecasts. The year was also driven by other franchises still seeing unit sales but more importantly, as we move towards streaming/subscriptions: paid-for updates. It has been well flagged that FY20 will decline due to the exceptional showing of JWE in FY19, thanks to its brand and multi-platform releases. Unlike last year, the new release, Planet Zoo (PZo) isn’t out yet. However, there are indications PZo is being well received, and the potential from its new publishing strategy (immaterial in FY20) could see upgrades in later years. FDEV on 16x CY20 EBITDA, versus the first quartile on 19x. Reiterate Buy, given operating leverage over the coming years.

wayneJ Key issue for FDEV is next year.
BE12:06pm

What to expect this year and beyond. For this year, revenue guidance of £65-73m, slightly below us at the mid-point, with consensus in the middle. We make no changes. The reduction yoy has been well flagged given the halo of the JW. Moreover, JWE launched on PC/PS4/XboxOne, whereas PZo will mirror its Planet Coaster (PCo) predecessor: PC only. Beyond, FDEV continues to invest for its future (120+ hired this year), expect more IP licences (Universal used for Back to the Future too), and is starting out on Frontier Publishing (first partner is Haemimont), to be material in the long term. Because of all of this, FDEV has moved away from ticking off franchise numbers to retain roadmap flexibility.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

The numbers as solid. Revenue slightly ahead of the trading update (£89.7m versus c£89m), but above the top end of the guidance range this time last year. Operating margin at 22%, versus c21% in the update. Gross profit of £54.6m saw a margin of 61% (71% PY). This was driven by JWE – royalties to Universal, digital platform fees, and physical sales. R&D of £21.2m (£15.9m PY) solidifies its future and reflects a greater level of outsourced resource. Capitalisation of R&D at £14.8m implies 70% of total (85% PY) due to more updates that don’t directly generate revenue. Because of this, a positive impact from working capital, and the extra bonuses are paid in Sep, cash grew from £24.1m to £35.3m.A few nuggets. JWE saw 1m units after five weeks, and 2m after seven months, we think around 2.1m for the full year generating around £65m revenue. On top of unit sales, JWE has five separate paid-for updates, and has benefitted from a number of free updates. PCo passed 2m units in Jan-19 and continues to help drive revenue with eleven separate paid-for updates to date. Elite Dangerous (ED) is the biggest selling franchise to date and crossed 3m units in Jan-19. Streaming is also a hot topic at the moment (Stadia, Sony/Microsoft “Memo”, etc.). FDEV focuses on rich content that is currently confined to PC/Console. However, streaming could bring those rich games to mobile and tablet users too – opening up a 2bn player market. We would guess that games that require physics-based, AI-led models (such as ED, PC, JWE) could do well when barriers to entry (eg hardware) are removed
